intro: Lamottea caerulea, commonly known as the blue bellflower, is a flowering plant belonging to the Campanulaceae family. It is characterized by its striking blue or violet bell-shaped flowers that bloom in early summer. Native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia, this plant thrives in well-drained soils and full sun to partial shade. Lamottea caerulea typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with slender stems and narrow, lance-shaped leaves. It is often cultivated for its ornamental value in gardens and is also valued for its ecological benefits to pollinators.
